criteria: Accuracy of Data Representation: How accurately the student represents the amounts of salt water and fresh water in various reservoirs.
Clarity of Graph and Description: How clearly the student presents the information in graph form and describes the distribution of water.
Use of Mathematical Thinking: How effectively the student uses mathematical thinking (e.g., proportions, percentages) to represent the distribution of water.
Evidence-Based Reasoning: How well the student provides evidence from their data to support their description of water distribution.
descriptions: The student does not attempt to represent the data, or the representation is completely inaccurate.
The student's data representation contains significant inaccuracies and omissions, indicating a poor understanding of the data.
The student's data representation has some inaccuracies and omissions, but the overall trend is discernible.
The student's data representation is mostly accurate with only minor errors. All required reservoirs are represented.
The student's data representation is accurate and complete, showing a clear understanding of the distribution of water on Earth.

The student's data representation is exceptionally accurate, complete, and insightful, demonstrating a deep understanding of the distribution of water on Earth, and providing additional relevant details.

The graph is clear, well-labeled, and easy to understand. The description is thorough and clearly explains the distribution of water on Earth.
The graph and description are exceptionally clear, insightful, and well-organized. The student demonstrates a sophisticated understanding through effective communication.
